title: Rapidly switch to or create worktree tab with M-S-o
description:
Implement M-S-o command that shows a completing-read prompt for existing worktrees. If the user enters a non-matching input, create a new worktree under .worktrees/ with that input as the branch name. The completing-read should validate input to ensure only legal git branch names are accepted.

When opening a new tab for a worktree:
- Open dired at the worktree root
- Start a claude-code-ide instance for that worktree

If the tab already exists, simply switch to it.
acceptance_criteria:
- M-S-o opens a completing-read prompt showing existing worktrees
- Entering a non-matching name creates a new worktree under .worktrees/ with that branch name
- Input validation prevents illegal git branch names
- New tabs open with dired at worktree root
- New tabs have a claude-code-ide instance running for that worktree
- Existing tabs are switched to rather than recreated

title: Fix Claude Code IDE scrolling behavior in eat window
description:
The Claude Code IDE currently runs in an eat terminal window, but has two scrolling issues:

**Problem 1: Over-scrolling beyond buffer content**
It's possible to scroll beyond the actual number of lines in the buffer, causing content to end up at the top of the screen with empty space below. Emacs should prevent scrolling past the actual buffer content.

**Problem 2: Not auto-scrolling to bottom on window focus**
When hiding/deleting the window or switching to another frame, then returning to the claude-code-ide buffer, it remains at the previous scroll position even if new content was written. The buffer should automatically scroll to the bottom (to keep the text entry at the bottom of the window) when switching back to the buffer/window.

For dedicated frames (project-specific frames), use the frame's dedicated project name. This will provide better context when working with multiple projects across different frames. Should leverage tab-bar's customization hooks like tab-bar-tab-name-function or tab-bar-tab-name-format-function.

This will make snippet expansion work more intuitively in markdown mode without losing the existing cycling behavior when snippets aren't applicable.

title: Investigate **loose** buffer save prompt when killing buffers
description:
When trying to kill an unsaved buffer, Emacs also prompts whether to save a buffer called **loose**. This behavior is unexpected and needs investigation to determine which package is creating this buffer.

## Reproduction Steps

1. Open a buffer for editing a file
2. Make unsaved changes to the buffer
3. Modify the underlying file externally (e.g., with Claude or another process)
4. Try to kill the buffer (e.g., with kill-buffer or by re-visiting the file)
5. User is prompted whether to kill, given there are unsaved edits
6. User selects 'yes' and the buffer is killed
7. BUG: A **loose** buffer then becomes active, with a 'do you want to kill' prompt for this one too

## Hypothesis

This appears to be related to file conflict detection when:
- Buffer has unsaved changes
- Underlying file is modified externally
- User attempts to kill the buffer

The **loose** buffer name pattern suggests it may be created by a package handling file conflicts or external modifications (possibly auto-revert or a conflict resolution package).
notes:
## Investigation Lead: Apheleia

Apheleia handles buffer formatting asynchronously and could be creating the **loose** buffer as part of its async formatting process.

Possible mechanism:
- Apheleia creates temporary buffers to handle async formatting
- When buffer has unsaved changes + external file modification + user kills buffer
- Apheleia's temporary buffer might not be properly cleaned up
- The **loose** buffer becomes visible and prompts for save

### Investigation Steps
1. Check if `apheleia-mode` is enabled in affected buffers
2. Look at apheleia's temporary buffer creation logic
3. Test reproduction with apheleia disabled
4. Check apheleia's buffer cleanup on kill-buffer
5. Search for "loose" string in apheleia source code

title: Add marginalia to bd issue selector for worktree, tab, and claude-code status
description:
The bd issue selector in the worktree transient is useful for spinning up worktrees or switching to existing ones. It would be more helpful if it displayed status indicators showing:
- Whether there is an existing worktree for the issue
- Whether there is a dedicated tab for the issue
- The current claude-code status (e.g., idle, working, waiting for input)

This would provide at-a-glance visibility into agent progress and workspace state without needing to navigate to each issue. This complements the broader bd integration work in emacs-67066ad8.

title: Debug issue creation function - process killed with signal 9
description:
The bd issue creation function (+bd-issue-create-with-claude) is failing with error "killed: 9" after the Claude Code process completes.

Error message:
```
Enter issue details. C-c C-c to create, C-c C-k to cancel.
Creating issue via Claude Code...done
Issue creation with Claude failed: killed: 9
```

Need to investigate why the process is being killed with SIGKILL and fix the error handling/process management.
notes:
Root cause is likely that the Claude Code one-shot session doesn't call mcp__plugin_beads_beads__set_context before trying to call mcp__plugin_beads_beads__create.

The MCP beads server requires set_context to be called first to establish the workspace_root and database path. Without this, the create call fails.

Fix: Ensure the prompt passed to Claude Code includes instructions to call set_context with the workspace root before attempting to create the issue.

description: When claude-code-ide is waiting for user interaction (e.g., approval for tool use, user input, or decision points) and the relevant tab or frame is not currently focused, it should send a desktop notification to alert the user. This would prevent users from missing prompts when they've switched to another application or Emacs frame/tab while Claude is working.

title: Add tab attributes for alert state with visual indicators
description:
Add support for tab attributes that represent an 'alert' state. Tabs with this attribute should have a visually distinct appearance to draw attention.

Provide a function `(defun +worktrees-alert (worktree-path &optional message))` that sets up the alert state for a given tab.

Support an `alert-message` attribute that stores an optional message. When the user selects a tab with an alert, create a `*tab-alert <tab-name>*` buffer with the message and display it using `display-buffer` (configured to display at the top side in the display-buffer module).

The alert state should automatically clear after a couple of seconds if the user stays on the tab - selecting an alerted tab should kick off a timer to handle this cleanup.
design:
## Implementation Details

### Tab Attributes
- Add `alert` attribute (boolean) to tab-bar tabs
- Add `alert-message` attribute (string, optional) to store message content

### Visual Appearance
- Modify tab-bar face/formatting for tabs with `alert` attribute
- Use distinct color/style (e.g., highlight, different foreground color)
- Integrate with existing tab-bar-format customizations

### Alert Function
```elisp
(defun +worktrees-alert (worktree-path &optional message)
  "Set alert state on tab associated with WORKTREE-PATH.
Optional MESSAGE will be displayed when tab is selected.")
```

### Message Display
- On tab selection, check for `alert` attribute
- If present and `alert-message` exists:
  - Create buffer: `*tab-alert <tab-name>*`
  - Insert message content
  - Use `display-buffer` (top side window per display-buffer config)

### Auto-Clear Mechanism
- When alerted tab is selected, start timer (2-3 seconds)
- Timer callback removes `alert` and `alert-message` attributes
- Cancel timer if user switches away before it fires
- Use `tab-bar-select-tab-hook` or similar to detect tab selection
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Tabs with alert attribute display visually distinct from normal tabs
- [ ] `+worktrees-alert` function sets alert state on correct tab
- [ ] Alert messages display in top-side buffer when alerted tab is selected
- [ ] Alert state automatically clears after ~2 seconds when staying on tab
- [ ] Alert state persists if user quickly switches away and back
- [ ] No errors when alert set on non-existent or invalid worktree path

title: Add command to worktree transient for creating bd issues via Claude Code
description:
Create a command in the worktree transient that allows creating bd issues interactively using Claude Code. 

Workflow:
1. User invokes command from worktree transient
2. Opens a buffer (git-commit-style) for composing the issue description
3. User types what they want to tell the LLM about the issue
4. C-c C-k aborts and closes the buffer
5. C-c C-c sends buffer contents to a Claude Code one-shot session running in the repo root
6. Claude Code creates the bd issue based on the description
7. Display desktop notification when issue is successfully created

This provides a natural way to leverage Claude's understanding to create well-structured issues without leaving Emacs, and integrates smoothly with the existing worktree workflow.

title: Worktree close command fails git operations due to incorrect working directory
description:
The command to close a beads issue from a worktree and merge changes into main is broken. It successfully destroys the tab and claude-code-ide session, but fails on git operations because they're running in the wrong working directory.

**Error from magit command log:**
```
128 .git/worktrees/ git … switch main
fatal: this operation must be run in a work tree

128 .git/worktrees/ git … merge --no-edit emacs-14-add-c-command-to-worktree-transient-to-open-claude-code-ide-buffer
fatal: this operation must be run in a work tree
```

The git commands are being executed in `.git/worktrees/` instead of the actual work tree directory, causing them to fail. The commands need to run in the proper working directory (either the main repo or the worktree directory).

title: Fix inconsistent all-the-icons font rendering on work MacBook
description: The all-the-icons fonts render inconsistently on work MacBook. For example, in mod-tabs.el, the git branch icon renders correctly in buffer text, but when displayed in a tab bar, it uses the java icon instead. This issue does not occur on personal MacBook, suggesting a difference in installations or font configuration between the two machines.

title: Investigate tab groups
description:
Research tab groups functionality in Emacs to understand how it works and whether it could be useful for organizing tabs in addition to or instead of the current tab-bar implementation.

Potential use case: Tab groups might be a useful alternative to having multiple Emacs frames for organizing different workspaces or contexts. Since it's a newer feature, need to understand:
- How tab groups differ from tab-bar tabs
- Whether they can replace multi-frame workflows
- Integration possibilities with current tab-bar setup
- Pros/cons compared to frames

title: magit-status shows error in magit-log-format-author-margin with symbol interpretation
description:
Opening magit-status triggers an error in `magit-log-format-author-margin` where it attempts to interpret a symbol as a number. This doesn't reproduce on a clean magit install, suggesting a configuration interaction issue.

Current workaround: An advice override in modules/mod-magit.el:205-238 handles the error by checking if width is a symbol (specifically `magit-log-margin-width`) and treating it as 0.

The advice includes a HACK comment indicating this is a temporary fix rather than addressing the root cause.
design:
Investigation needed to determine:
1. What configuration is causing `magit-log-margin-width` (or similar) to be passed as a symbol instead of a number
2. Whether this is due to package load order, deferred loading, or a conflicting customization
3. The proper fix - either correcting the configuration source or improving how the width value is resolved

Areas to investigate:
- Custom magit margin settings in the config
- Package initialization order (Elpaca-related timing?)
- Any other magit-related advices or customizations
- Whether `magit--right-margin-config` is being set correctly
acceptance_criteria:
- Root cause identified and documented
- Either: proper configuration fix applied, OR justification for keeping the advice with improved documentation
- No error when opening magit-status
- Magit margin displays correctly with author and date information
